captions.text:
Unless you happen to own a ski resort or a
snowplow business or live in the southern

hemisphere, you’re probably tired of seeing
them by now.

But during this seemingly incessant winter,
did you get a chance to take a good, hard
look at a snowflake?

If I asked you to imagine a snowflake, you’d
probably envision something like this -- six

glistening arms radiating out from the center
of a perfectly symmetrical crystal.

And, yeah, some of them look all intricate
and mathematically precise, but they're the

special ones -- the outliers that catch our
attention and end up knitted into our ugly
sweaters.

Usually, though, snowflakes look all lumpy
and awkward. Like this.

And how a snowflake looks -- whether it’s
sweater-worthy or not -- has a whole lot to

do with how it first formed, and what happened
to it after it started to fall.

Snowflakes form when it’s cold enough for
water vapor in the air to change directly
into ice, a process known as deposition.

And when ice starts to crystallize, a snow
crystal is born.

This snow crystal is just the precursor to
the snowflakes you see on the ground, which

are usually made of lots of different snow
crystals clumped together.

Now water tends to form hexagonal crystals
because of the nature of its molecules.

Water, as you know, is H20 that’s one oxygen
and two hydrogens, but it isn’t a linear

molecule -- the hydrogen atoms are crooked
because there are these two unbonded electrons

at the top of the oxygen atom pushing those
hydrogen atoms down so it’s in sort of a
triangular shape.

The oxygen end of the water molecule is slightly
negative in charge, while the hydrogens are
slightly positive.

So, as cold temperatures slow these molecules
down, and they start to coalesce from a gas

into a solid, the positive ends of the molecules
are drawn to the negative ends of others.

And when these vaguely triangular molecules
snap together like this, they typically form
a hexagon.

And this hexagon becomes the center of the
crystal, and the foundation upon which the
rest of the snowflake can grow.

Eventually, when enough water molecules have
come together, and the ice crystal becomes
heavier, it begins to fall.

But here’s the thing: The shape that crystals
can take vary considerably, depending on both
the temperature and humidity in the atmosphere.

Specifically, snowflakes tend to form bigger,
more intricate patterns when more moisture

is in the air, while snowflakes produced in
drier conditions tend to have simpler forms.

Basically, the less water there is in the
air, the less interesting your crystal is
going to be.

For example, the ugly-sweater crystals, which
are often called stellar dendrites, form at

temperatures from -16 to -12 degrees Celsius
-- or sometimes a little warmer -- but only
when the air contains a fair amount of moisture.

These kinds of flakes are relatively rare,
because these conditions are relatively rare.

For one thing, -16 to -12 degrees is a fairly
narrow temperature window.

And, since colder air is usually drier, it’s
even less likely that the air will also have
enough humidity to form dendrites.

Without that humidity, snow crystal shapes
are much less frilly.

In the -16 to -12 range, for example, less
saturated air forms boring, solid, six-sided
plates.

And at many other temperatures, you don’t
even get plates. Above -10 and below -20,

you often see fat, stout kinds of crystals
called columns, or long, spindly needles instead.

But even these relatively dull patterns need
stable, almost laboratory-like conditions

in order to form. And winter weather isn’t
exactly known for its stability.

The fact is, snowflakes actually take their
full shape as they fall.

And as snow crystals fall, the conditions
around them -- like humidity, wind, and temperature
-- also change.

So as each crystal passes through a mix of
different temperatures and moisture levels,

it ends up with different patterns all trying
to form on top of each other -- a kind of

frankenstein’s monster of dendrites and
discs and needles and other shapes.

That’s why the vast majority of snowflakes
are weird, asymmetrical blobs, which have
been politely referred to as irregular crystals.

So, maybe you like them, maybe after this
winter you never want to see them again. But

at least now you know that the stuff you’ve
been shoveling and skiing on didn’t actually
look like what you were wearing on your sweater.
